page.title: 08OTLEY _THE CHANGING TIMES
page.content: Before the first World War, just the town centre had been built. The surrounding land was mainly fields. At the end of the last century, the main jobs in Otley were in printing. Printers and engineering companies were Waite and Saville, and Bremners. Other jobs were in Ackroyds Mills, weaving cloth. Child labour was no longer existent, and the three R's were taught in Primary schools. Some mills had their own schools to teach part-timers. Walking on the Chevin was popular, as was music and singing. At Christmas families went to the Pantomime at Leeds. With World War ll came rationing and food was scarce. Animal victims were cut up for food. Housing was mainly Victorian terracing with out-door toilets. There were often only two bedrooms with coal fires in every room.
